original_conversation.content: [shaky voice] Marcus just cleaned out his desk. Twenty-three years he's been here and they just— [pause] they escorted him out like he was some kind of criminal. [bitter] All because of that press malfunction on Tuesday. [anxious] The one where the rollers jammed and tore through that entire print run? [very quietly] Except it wasn't his fault. [regretful] He showed me exactly how to reset the tension calibration, told me three times to never force it past the red marker. [stuttering] But I was— I was in a hurry, trying to impress everyone with how fast I could get things done. [guilty pause] And when it happened, when everything went sideways, I just stood there. [mumbling] Let him take the blame. [upset] He didn't even defend himself, just kept saying he must have missed something in the maintenance check. [crying while speaking] The way he looked at me when they called him into the office... [sniffle] I think he knew. [very sad] But he didn't say anything, didn't throw me under the bus or anything. [frustrated] God, I should say something, right? [hesitantly] I mean, I need this job too, I've got rent, student loans, but that's not— that's not an excuse. [angry] What kind of person just watches someone lose their whole career over, um, over something that took me thirty seconds to screw up? subject: The bindery worker who trained you just got fired for the machine malfunction you actually caused
